reference.volume-title: History of the Catholic Charismatic Renewal in Ghana

reference.unstructured: 1974.Theological and Pastoral Orientations on the Catholic Charismatic Renewal, Malines Document no. 1 31Ann Arbor, Michigan: Servant Books. This is the term used in Ghana for the “baptism in the Spirit,” which can be described as a “breaking forth into conscious experience of the Spirit who was given during the celebration of initiation.” See, Among the many fine treatments of the charismatic experience in the Roman Catholic church is that of Francis A. Sullivan, S.J.Charismatic Renewal: A Biblical and Theological Study(Ann Arbor, Michigan: Servant Books, 1982), especially pp. 59–75 on the “baptism in the Spirit.”

Sarpong, Peter K. 1974.Ghana in Retrospect: Some Aspects of Ghanaian Culture, 14–19. Accra-Tema: Ghana Publishing. For a description of the meaning and place of “minor deities” within Akan traditional religion, see
1984. This was the theme of the Fifth International Charismatic Leaders' Conference. May1984, Rome.

A very small percentage of Ghanaian catholics celebrate the sacrament of matrimony after observing the traditional rites of marriage in their ethnic group. Among the reasons for this are the reluctance to “bless the marriage” until children have been born and fear of the indissolubility of the marriage as understood in the church. For background on christian marriage in Africa, see “Families: Truly Christian, Truly African,” the proceedings of the Ninth Plenary of the AMECEA Conference, inAfrican Ecclesial Review28 (June-August 1986): 155–287; Kisembo, Benezeri et al.African Christian Marriage(London: Geoffrey Chapman, 1977); “Marriage in Africa,” Pro Mundi Vita: Dossiers (Brussels), 1(1986)
